title: 115_hr5270
content: The "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" includes a Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under SEC. 45T allows taxpayers who own or lease such units to claim a credit equal to 30% of qualified expenses or $13 multiplied by the unit's capacity rating. The units must use coal for at least 75% of electricity production. Qualified expenses include operation costs. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units allows taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified expenses related to the operation or maintenance of a coal-powered electric generation unit. Qualified public entities can transfer the credit to eligible project partners. The Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units allows qualified public entities to transfer the credit to eligible project partners. Definitions for qualified public entity and eligible project partner are provided. The term 'eligible project partner' refers to any person involved in operating, maintaining, repairing, providing coal, financing, or leasing a coal-powered electric generation unit. Special rules apply for partnerships where a qualified public entity is treated as the entity receiving the tax credit. The term 'eligible project partner' includes any partner of a partnership. Credits are taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner after the qualified public entity's taxable year. Transfer of benefits is subject to private use rules. For section 141(b)(1), benefits from an election under this subsection are not considered private business use. A basis adjustment is made for coal-powered electric generation units receiving a credit under this section. The section applies to taxable years from 2018 to 2022. A conforming amendment is made to section 501(c)(12)(I). The credit can be used against the alternative minimum tax. The text chunk describes an amendment to section 45T of the tax code, with clauses being redesignated and a new clause being inserted. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendment to section 45T of the tax code includes redesignating clauses and inserting a new clause related to coal-powered electric generation unit credit.
